newsitem.title: USA: NYMEX Nov electricity expires up, sets new highs.
newsitem.headline: NYMEX Nov electricity expires up, sets new highs.

text.p: NYMEX November electricity futures closed sharply higher on Monday after setting new contract highs on strength in natural gas prices and emerging heating demand in the northwestern U.S.
A price hike of daily offers by Bonneville Power Administration (BPA) also bolstered both cash and futures prices in the western U.S., brokers and marketers said.
Cold weather combined with strong demand for strong injection into storage rallied natural gas prices in the West and Canada for the second day.

Spot natgas prices jumped on average 15 to 20 cents today compared with Friday's values. The benchmark value at Henry Hub offshore Louisiana for swing delivery was quoted at $2.71-$2.74 per million British thermal units, up sharply from Friday's range of $2.42-$2.45.
November California-Oregon Border (COB) futures expired up 64 cents at $21.92 a megawatt hour (MWh), almost halving the gain from a life-of-contract high at $22.95.
December COB finished up $1.17 at $22.50. Deferred COB contracts ended five to $1.25 higher than Friday's close.
November Palo Verde (PV) futures expired up $1.17 at $20.67 after hitting a new contract at $20.95.
December PV finished up $1.30 at $20.00, off from a high of $20.50. Other PV months ended 10 cents to a dollar higher.
The rally in the NYMEX electricity complex was expected to continue when December futures debut as the spot contracts open Tuesday.
"In a normal case I would say 'no' but nobody wants to pick the top here, natgas just keeps getting stronger," a Houston trader said.
"I think there's still some room on the upside," echoed another Houston trader, but cautioned the complex could ready tumble on bearish weather forecasts.
In the next six to 10 days, the western U.S. were predicted to experience normal to warmer-than-normal autumn weather.
